message_1: Suppose the weights of 50 students in a school are normally distributed with a mean of 60 kilograms and a standard deviation of 5 kilograms. What is the probability that a randomly selected student weighs more than 65 kilograms?
message_2:
To find the probability that a randomly selected student weighs more than 65 kilograms, we can use the z-score formula to standardize the value and then use the standard normal distribution table (also known as the z-table) to find the probability.

The z-score formula is:

z = (X - μ) / σ

where X is the value we want to standardize (65 kg in this case), μ is the mean (60 kg), and σ is the standard deviation (5 kg).

z = (65 - 60) / 5
z = 5 / 5
z = 1

Now that we have the z-score, we can look up the probability in the standard normal distribution table. The table gives us the probability that a value is less than the given z-score. Since we want the probability that a student weighs more than 65 kg, we need to find the complement of the probability given by the table.

The probability for a z-score of 1 is 0.8413. This means that there is an 84.13% chance that a randomly selected student weighs less than 65 kg. To find the probability that a student weighs more than 65 kg, we subtract this value from 1:

P(X > 65) = 1 - P(X < 65)
P(X > 65) = 1 - 0.8413
P(X > 65) = 0.1587

So, there is a 15.87% chance that a randomly selected student weighs more than 65 kilograms.
